intro: Chapmannia, commonly known as the white sage, is a perennial herb native to the arid regions of the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It belongs to the family Lamiaceae, which includes many aromatic plants known for their medicinal and culinary uses. The plant features square, hairy stems and opposite, lance-shaped leaves that are often covered in a fine, whitish coating. Its small, tubular flowers are typically purple or blue, arranged in whorled clusters along the stem. Chapmannia is valued for its aromatic properties and has been traditionally used by indigenous peoples for ceremonial and healing purposes.
